lexUnit.name: toll.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: (with reference to a bell) sound or cause to sound with a slow, uniform succession of strokes.

sentence.text: Even the soldiers , when they are drunk , keep clear of the area in case they stumble and start the bell tolling . "
The church bell was tolling mournfully as the carriage entered the cemetery gate .
There were warning bells tolling in his head .
It was as if a harvest festival were enacted daily , for throughout the hours of market the church bell tolled quietly .
Patrick awoke again as the church bells all across London were tolling noon .
The next morning when the bells of the abbey tolled for Prime , the first prayer of the monastic day , Corbett was up , dressed and gently kicked a sleepy , grunting Ranulf awake .
On summer evenings rowers on the lake have claimed that they have heard far below them through the still waters the sound of church bells tolling .
A bell tolled above his head .
Outside , standing on a beer barrel , a member of the ward watch rang a hand bell which tolled like a death knell through the noisy clamour of the place .
Like many lakes , Semer Water has its legendary sunken village or town , complete with underwater church bells tolling as storm winds move the surface of the lake .
For hours he would sit by the window , and look out on the empty , Sunday street , as the church bells tolled dismally from different points in the town .
A bell tolled , the sign for Compline , and Lady Amelia led him down through the darkened cloister out across the grass to the church .

Whichever bell was tolling , the question-and-answer on the specific issue of the FBR revealed that the committee was dealing with a legendary creature indifferent to the usual processes of judgement , time and fate .
Mowbray 's hand fell to his sword hilt as he realised that great brass tongue only tolled when the Tower was under attack .
Everything 's changed , she thought , and the word tolled in her mind -- changed , changed , changed .
